facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 247 of 1954 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 247 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated July 21, 1953 of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Third Bench, Lucknow in Appeal No. Calcutta 44 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 21, 19 53 of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Third Bench, Lucknow in Appeal. No. Calcutta 44 of 1952.

facts.text: Appellant is a limited company carrying on business in crushing sugarcane at Pipraich in Gorakhpur District from 1932.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a limited Company, which had been carrying on business in crushing sugarcane at a place called Pipraich in Gorakhpur District from the year 1932.

facts.text: In 1946, appellant decided to expand business, sold old machinery of 160 tons capacity, purchased new one with 650 tons capacity.

anchor.surface_text: In 1946 it decided to expand its business, and with that object, sold its old machinery which had a crushing capacity of 160 tons per day, and purchased a new one with 650 tons capacity.

facts.text: New plant installed in 1947, started working in 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: The new plant was installed in 1947, and it actually started working in 1948-49.

facts.text: Sugar industry crisis due to shortage of sugarcane, Government assumed control of production and supply.

anchor.surface_text: During this period, the sugar industry was passing through a crisis owing to shortage of sugarcane, and in companysequence, the Government assumed companytrol of its production and supply.

facts.text: Quota allotted to appellant's mill too small, losses in 1948-49 and 1949-50 of Rs. 2,67,042-7-4 according to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The quota which was allotted to the appellants Mill proved too small to its being worked profitably, with the result that in 1948-49 and 1949-50 the Company sustained losses which according to the appellant came to Rs. 2,67 042-7-4.

facts.text: On May 11, 1950, management wrote to Government to increase quota or permit sale of mills.

anchor.surface_text: After several unsuccessful attempts at setting a larger supply, the management wrote to the Government on May 11, 1950, either to increase their quota or to permit them to sell the Mills.

facts.text: In October 1950, Government granted permission for sale of plant and machinery.

anchor.surface_text: In October, 1950, the Government granted permission for the sale of the plant and machinery, and pursuant thereto, the management sold them to a Madras party.

facts.text: Management sold plant and machinery to Madras party, obtained lease for current crushing season.

anchor.surface_text: and pursuant thereto, the management sold them to a Madras party. As the crushing season was then on, the appellant obtained from the purchaser a lease of the Mills for the current season

facts.text: Workmen through union decided to prevent sale to avoid unemployment, moved Government to cancel permission.

anchor.surface_text: When the workmen became aware of the agreement of sale, their reaction to it was thoroughly hostile, and acting through their union, the respondent herein, they decided to prevent the transaction going through, as otherwise they would be thrown out of employment.

facts.text: Union passed resolution on December 26, 1950 to go on strike from January 12, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: and they also passed a resolution on December 26, 1950, to go on strike from January 12, 1951, and companymunicated the same to the appellant.

facts.text: On January 3, 1951, Managing Director offered 25% profit on sale to Madras party if strike notice withdrawn.

anchor.surface_text: On January 3, 1951, the Managing Director offered through the Manager of the Mills, to allot 25 per cent. of the profit on the sale transaction with the Madras party on certain terms

facts.text: Union replied on January 5, 1951 refusing to withdraw strike notice, fight with Government.

anchor.surface_text: To this, the reply of the Union on January 5, 1951, was as follows With reference to the assurance given by the Managing Director, companymunicated by your goodself to us under your No. 975 dated 4th January 1951,

facts.text: Strike did not take place, crushing continued till end of January 1951.

anchor.surface_text: After this, the appellant did number hear from the respondent, the strike also did number take place, and the crushing went on till the end of January, 1951, when the season came to an end.

facts.text: Notice dated February 28, 1951: workers to cooperate in dismantling or discharged from March 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: the management put up the following numberice on February 28, 1951 The workers of Pipraich. Sagar Mills Ltd. should know that we have sold our Mill to Madras party under the permission of the Government.

facts.text: Workers discharged from services since March 1, 1951 per notice March 14, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Now in pursuance of our numberice dated 28-2-1951, it is numberified that the following workers have been discharged from the services since 1-3-1951

facts.text: Government letter dated March 21, 1951 declined to interfere with sale.

anchor.surface_text: But the Government declined by its letter dated March 21, 1951, to interfere with the sale of the machinery,

facts.text: Appellant lost contract for dismantling, profit of at least Rs. 2 lakhs as admitted by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The net result was that the appellant lost a companytract on which, as admitted by the respondent, it would have earned a profit of at least Rs. 2 lakhs.

facts.text: U.P. Government issued notification on November 16, 1951 under section 3 of U.P. Industrial Disputes Act referring dispute to Industrial Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: the result was that on November 16,1951, the U. P. Government issued a numberification under section 3 of the U. P. Industrial Disputes Act XXVIII of 1947, hereinafter referred to as the Act,

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal award dated February 28, 1952 held closure bona fide, conduct unfair but promise binding, awarded Rs. 45,000.

anchor.surface_text: By its award dated February 28,1952, the Indus- trial Tribunal held firstly that the closure of the business and the sale of the machinery by the appellant was bona fide,

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed on July 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The management appealed against this decision but the same was companyfirmed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal by its order dated July 21, 1953.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: The matter number companyes before us. in appeal under art. 136.

facts.text: Court held no concluded binding agreement for 25% profits.

anchor.surface_text: It is impossible to hold on these facts that there was a companycluded agreement between the parties binding the appellant to give the workmen a share of the profits of the sale transaction.

facts.text: Court set aside the award of compensation.

anchor.surface_text: And as we have found against the agreement, we must allow this appeal, and set aside the award of companypensation to the workmen made by the Tribunal.

art. 136. As the appeal raised questions of importance, and as the respondent was unrepresented we requested Mr. Umrigar to assist us, and we are indebted to him for his learned and comprehensive argument.

the U. P. Government issued a notification under section 3 of the U. P. Industrial Disputes Act XXVIII of 1947, hereinafter referred to as the Act, referring the following dispute to the adjudication of the Industrial Tribunal

concepts.interpretation: Power to refer industrial dispute for adjudication if it arose out of an existing industry, even if industry closed by date of reference; competence determined by date dispute arose, not date of notification.
concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for referring industrial disputes for conciliation or adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: An industrial dispute, as defined in s. 2 k of the Industrial Disputes Act XIV of 1947-and by force of section 2, that definition applies to the Actmeans any dispute or difference between employers and employees

concepts.interpretation: Requires continued existence of employer-employee relationship and existing industry for dispute to qualify; applies to disputes arising from existing industry.
Appellate Tribunal bound to accept findings of fact by Industrial Tribunal.

concepts.unlisted_description: Limits on appellate review of fact findings.

concepts.interpretation: Does not comprehend discharge on closure of business; retrenchment means discharge of surplus labour while business continues.

holdings.text: The notification dated November 16, 1951 under section 3 of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act referring the dispute is competent and not ultra vires, as the dispute arose while the industry was existing, even though the industry was closed by the date of notification.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 3 requires industrial dispute from existing industry; competence determined by date dispute arose, not notification; policy avoids anomalies like escaping liability by closure.

holdings.text: The power under section 3 does not require continued existence of industry on date of notification if dispute arose earlier in existing industry.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.3; distinguishes precedents requiring existing industry for dispute arising; reference valid post-closure if right accrued earlier.

holdings.text: There was no concluded and binding agreement between the parties for the appellant to pay 25% of profits on sale to workmen.

anchor.surface_text: It is impossible to hold on these facts that there was a concluded agreement between the parties binding the appellant to give the workmen a share of the profits of the sale transaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No unconditional acceptance of conditional offer to withdraw strike; inconsistent conduct by workmen refusing cooperation; Tribunal findings internally inconsistent allowing review.

holdings.text: The right to share of profits arose in praesenti on January 3/10, 1951 while industry existed, payable later on completion.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Offer created present right, quantification deferred; thus dispute timely for reference.

holdings.text: Termination of services of all workmen on closure of business is not retrenchment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary meaning: surplus discharge while business continues, not total closure; unnecessary to decide due to amendment timing.

holdings.text: Sections 2(oo) and 25F of Industrial Disputes Act 1947 as inserted by 1953 Amendment Act have no retrospective operation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Burn & Co.; rights determined by law at discharge date (March 1951), pre-amendment.

holdings.text: Closure of business and sale of machinery was bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: the Industrial Tribunal held firstly that the closure of the business and the sale of the machinery by the appellant was bona fide, as it had been continuously incurring losses

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts Tribunal fact finding: continuous losses, no sugarcane prospects; Appellate Tribunal bound by s.7.

holdings.text: Conduct of workmen was unfair throughout, disentitling them to compensation apart from any agreement.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Refusal to cooperate in dismantling, direct contract with purchaser causing loss to employer; agreed with Tribunal.
